facts.text: The respondent (assessee) was a dealer in Coconut oil business having inter-State sales.
For the year 1959-60, the assessee was assessed to sales-tax under s. 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.
Out of total turnover of Rs. 2,30,990, only Rs. 1,89,734 was supported by proper declaration Form C.
Sales Tax Officer imposed tax at 1% on turnover of Rs. 1,93,346 and at 7% on balance Rs. 37,645.
Assessee did not file declaration forms by prescribed date February 16, 1961, but filed on March 8, 1961 before assessment order dated June 13, 1961.
Delay in filing forms explained as due to late receipt from purchaser in Madras.
Assessee preferred appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner; appeal dismissed on December 13, 1961.
Assessee filed revision before Deputy Commissioner of Sales-tax; revision dismissed.

Assessee moved Kerala High Court in Writ Petition O.P. No. 2165 of 1962 under Art. 226 for quashing orders of Sales Tax Officer (June 13, 1961) and Appellate Assistant Commissioner (December 13, 1961).

Kerala High Court by order dated November 29, 1963 allowed writ petition, quashed assessment orders, directed Sales Tax Officer to make fresh assessment considering declaration forms furnished on March 8, 1961.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the third proviso to Rule 6(1) of Central Sales Tax (Kerala) Rules prescribing deadline of February 16, 1961 for filing Form C declarations is ultra vires s.8(4) read with s.13 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.
Whether the assessee was entitled to lower rate of tax under s.8(1) despite filing declarations after February 16, 1961 but before assessment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee had not filed declarations in Form C before February 16, 1961 as per third proviso to Rule 6(1); breach disentitles assessee to lower rate under s.8(1).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 6(1) third proviso; s.8(1) Central Sales Tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Third proviso to Rule 6(1) ultra vires s.8(4) read with s.13(4)(e).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.8(4), s.13(4)(e) Central Sales Tax Act

court_reasoning.text: Phrase 'in the prescribed manner' in s.8(4) confers power to prescribe particulars in form, nature/value of goods, parties, authority, but does not include time-limit for filing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Prescribed manner' does not take in time element.

court_reasoning.text: Supported by s.13(4)(g) which separately provides for rules on 'time within which' for other matters, showing Legislature conscious of distinction.
Stroud's Judicial Dictionary: 'manner and form' refer to mode, not time.
Acraman v. Herniman: 'manner and form' only mode, not time or thing to be done.
Note to Form C under Rule 12 Central Sales Tax (Registration & Turnover) Rules, 1957 refers to rules under s.13(4)(e) by State Govt.
Third proviso to Rule 6(1) ultra vires s.8(4) r/w s.13(3) and (4). Assessee must furnish within reasonable time; here filed March 8, 1961 before assessment, which is reasonable.

holdings.text: Third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires s.8(4) read with s.13(3) and (4) of Central Sales Tax Act.
Assessee complied with s.8(4)(a) by furnishing Form C within reasonable time before assessment.

precedents_cited.relevance: Words 'manner and form' refer only to mode, not time for doing the act.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: s.8(4) 'prescribed manner' interpreted not to include time-limit; s.13 rule-making powers limited.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax (Kerala) Rules, 1967
statutes_cited.relevance: Third proviso prescribing time-limit held ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax (Registration & Turnover) Rules, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Note to Form C refers to State rules under s.13(4)(e).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition in High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Supreme Court upheld Kerala High Court judgment quashing assessment orders and directing fresh assessment considering Form C declarations filed on March 8, 1961.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order affirmed; fresh assessment directed.

key_quotes.text: 'the phrase in the prescribed manner occurring in s. 8(4) of the Act only confers power on the rule-making authority to prescribe a rule stating what particulars are to be mentioned in the prescribed form... But the phrase... does not take in the time element.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'The words manner and form refer only to the mode in which the thing is to be done, and do not introduce anything from the Act referred to as to the thing which is to be done or the time for doing it.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Stroud and Acraman, key to holding proviso ultra vires.

key_quotes.text: For the reasons expressed, we hold that the third proviso to Rule 6(1) is ultra vires of s. 8(4) read with s.13(3) and (4) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
